Throat issues/LPR

Posted over a year ago

I am a 26 year old female from Toronto, Ontario, Canada. I found this forum when I was actively researching my diagnosis (LPR). I have been reading different topics, and decided to create a profile and maybe get some answers.  

So I have been dealing with throat issues for almost a year now. I basically had strep throat for 6 months straight (April - October). I was referred to an ENT who took my tonsils out on October 17th 2014. My throat infections have stopped, but now I am dealing with something called Laryngopharyngeal Reflux (Silent Reflux). When I am sleeping, acid comes up from my stomach and burns my esophagus, vocal cords and throat. I was put on a ppi called pantoprozole almost a month ago, and don't feel any relief yet. My voice has also been hoarse this whole time. I am not sure what to do anymore. This is definately effecting my life and I am soo tired of having terrible throat pain all day, every day! I am in desperate need of advice/support from people dealing with this same thing. Thanks for reading.

    You've a long term task ahead ""if "" you are serious

    Its diet and very minor exercise along with "positioning".

    Its possible your LES is impaired....often it is due to "medications"...if you are on any, check them out carefully to be sure they do not affect smooth or skeletal muscle. Or it could be your LES relaxes at some stage night time.

    Understand "positioning"...picture a plastic water bottle 3/4 full on the table with the lid loose, now squeeze the bottle in the center....you'll see the water is forced up, and if you've squeezed

    enough, water will escape from the top, and if not, the lid is yet too tight. (would be same as a good LES)

    Now put your fingers from both hands in the center of your rib cage where your stomach is and lift a leg....you'll feel the stomach contract...just like the head of a snare drum......meaning,

    what ever you have in your stomach can be "forced" upwards and against your LES.

    One of most destructive positions is after a meal by bending down...such as picking up something from the floor or putting on a shoe.

    .

    After meals, its best not to sit down, but to slow walk for at least 15 minutes...otherwise stay in a verticle

    position...never lie down after a meal, whatever you have in your stomach will press against your LES and constant pressure may cause the LES to further degrade...not to mention the stomachs digestive system can go "nuts"..

    You can start immediately.

    1. taper, ween the PPI..while it blocks the secretion of gastric juices, the results increase the volume ratio

    of HCL to pepsin, and bile acids. Pepsin and bile are "errosive". and pepsin can remain if it finds an opening and can continue to actively degrade your lining..only ph 8.2 plus can stop the activity...8.8 can

    eliminate it. (if on the surfance) (some studies show pepsin at 6.5 ph is inactive but err on prudence.)

    How to taper depends on your current dosage. It must be weened not stopped abruptly.

    2. elevate you head and shoulder night time..one method is to use a rice/pillow...you don't need to raise it to a kink, merely "elevate", and only a part of your shoulder. Some find the left shoulder/sode is more beneficial.

    3. to begin to heal your throat...use "sips" of 8.2 ph water often,

    and cut out all processed foods...

    4. limit or avoid all heavy oils and fats...i.e. no fried anything. obvious coffee/tea.soda will activate

    pepsin, and so will all fruit juices since they are around ph 4. Note...some avoid dairy and some do not.

    .

    5. last meal of the day should be well balanced without acidic type foods such as tomato, fruit juices etc.

    and do not retire within 3 plus hours of last meal.

    6. exercise....deep breathing..as often as you can....slow enhale...hold..slow exhale...this "may" strenghen

    the LES (but not scientificly proven)

    7. Some find that one tablet of Bismuth pre bed time helps...it may turn your stools black but that's normal

    And others find that 4 to 6 oz of 8.2 ph plus water pre bedtime helps.

    Google dr.j kaufman, she is an ENT top specialist in NY...she has published medical abstracts in several medical

    journals. She has a book "cut the acid" she had it published to spread the cause of LPS (she coined the phrase "silent reflux".

    nickandann

    Hi, I had some similiar symptoms, as well as burnt gums (burnt the enamel right off my teeth) and lips and quickly came to the conclusion that mainstream medicine wasn't going to come up with a lasting cure. I was freaking out that I may contract esophageal cancer later down the track and some days felt like I was in the process of dying. Most questions I asked were met with a blank stare, eg, why is this happening, and how can I make it stop without hardcore meds? The specialist told me flat out that I either stay on PPI's for the rest of my life or undergo a major operation and have fundoplication surgery, shudder. Thus began a quest in search of my health, and happily for me I didn't have the operation, and have been off PPI's for months and feel great again. It's been a journey and I learnt a lot about body and mind.

    Stress and anxiety made the symptoms worse and my doctor advised mindfulness meditation, which I'd got out of the habit of doing. It really helps.

    Getting diet right was a huge learning experience, as I thought I already ate well, and probably what works for one may be a bit different for another. I eat lots of organic raw sauerkraut, the refrigerated kind that hasn't been pasteurized. It's probiotic rich as is yogurt, which is also a great source of probiotics. You have to be vigilant about everything that goes in your mouth. If it makes it worse then don't eat or drink it. I developed, or maybe I always had, a sensitivity to gluten and dairy, so yogurt was out for me. I can eat them now if I want, but figure why take the chance. Probiotics are fantastic for the gut. I also take a really good probiotic capsule every morning. The one I take is from the health food store's fridge and has 8 different types of probiotic. I eat easy to digest food, even now as I kinda got into the habit. No meat, cheese, etc. If you can get it, eat good organic vegetarian food, at least until your well again. I also got into the habit of collecting and eating lots of Stinging Nettles. They were an old time fix for gut issues and they taste great in soups, scrambled eggs or teas. I still have them every day.

    It's hard to pinpoint what helped the most. I suspect a combination of lots of things, but what I know really helped a lot was acupuncture. I tried a couple of guys before I found the one, and he really helped bring me back from the brink. He treated me for high stomach acid, amongst other things.

    I was booked in for more tests by the specialist , as a precursor to the operation, and had to stop taking the PPI's for about 5 days in the lead-up to them. I was freaking out as about a month earlier I'd tried to cut them back just a little and had really bad rebound. Anyway, to cut a long story short, I stopped taking the PPI's expecting the worst, but nothing happened, so I canceled the tests and will hopefully live happily ever after. I hope you do too. Your health and recovery are really in your own hands.

    Best of luck

    cya

    Hi Teenanicole and anyone else with LPR. I have had LPR for more than 6 years now and have trying to find a solution since the doctors seem clueless. I have tried PPIs, Apple Cider Vinager, Probiotics (which help a little), wedge pillow, watching what I eat, etc.but I think I may have come across a solution from someone else that had posted on another site and what fixed his LPR and I believe he is right! My symptoms have ebbed and flowed over the years but never went away. It always seems worse during the winter too. I believe it's due to low vitamin D levels!! A few years ago through a routine blood test my doctor said I had a low Vitamine D level and gave me a months supply of 15000IU (I dont remember what my level was though). In additon, over the years I've struggles with IBS as well and feeling tired and my moods were sort of down. I alway thought my mood was because of my chronic LPR (maybe it was though). Anyhow I started researching low vitamin D and bad gut flora and there is a definate link!! As of a week ago, I'm taking 10000 IU of Vitamin D, Calcium 1000IU, and 1000IU of B12 a day, and probiotics and I can say my neck pain disappeared, throat pain gone,the lump in my has significantly reduced, Phlemg has also really reduced and mood and energy through the roof! I would recommend a visit to your doctor and have your D levels checked. I've read that some peole have to maintain this level of Vitamin D until they reach optimum of about 80-90 count in their bloodwork (sometimes 3 month or more). I will stay on it until all my symptoms are gone then reduce it to 1000 IU to maintain. I will also follow up with my Dr to have him check my D levels. This is my first post on this topic since this problem started and its the first time I really feel optimistic that this is the solution... for me anyway. I hope it works for all of you as well. Best of luck to everyone!!!
